A horror writer? Do you have published stuff thats available to read? :D
[This one was pretty popular.](https://medium.com/@jaredrosen/the-millennials-are-getting-worse-3f53e44cc569)

That was great. Let me go hang myself because my grasp and mastery of language will never be so utterly amazing, and the topics I want to write about will never be this fresh.

Edit, if you're still here: How do I git gud at style?

If you're looking to improve at writing I can boil it down into three basic tips: read more, write more, and put your work out where people can see it.

You need to be reading in the same way doctors need to go to medical conferences: you should know how language is evolving, what sorts of stories you're drawn to, what the rules of writing are and how you're able to convincingly break them without losing the reader. It also keeps your imagination sharp, which is most important.

Writing more is simply a good way to get better at the craft. Plus, you know, you have to write to... be a writer. You'll also, if you've been reading or consuming written media a lot, have a good sense of taste -- even if your skill level isn't quite meeting your own standards yet. Just keep making stuff. The things I wrote five years ago are nowhere near the quality I'm hitting today, and I suspect in five years I'll look back on my work now and find ways to improve it further.

Finally, you need feedback. Honest feedback. If you're surrounded by people who say your work can't possibly be improved you will never get better, ever. Get a peer group together and write with them. If at any point they all think your writing is consistently flawless, find a new writing group and start over. You can always, always, _always_ improve, so keep working at it and keep your mind open to new opinions or ideas.

As a side note, don't get too comfortable with your own work. A little humility goes a long way.

Thanks! I think the last one is the hardest. When it comes to League, the Boards Creations and Content Discord group is actually pretty good for sharing and feedback. Just putting this out there for whoever might be interested. Still, it's just fanfiction so the standards of such a community don't quite match the ambitions I have sometimes.

My reply won't be as good as his I'm sure, but in case he doesn't see this... I write a lot, and for me, I didn't have a style at first. I guess it's a bit like cooking. You sample a lot of foods and see what you like. Then you incorporate parts of different things into your own dish. I'd suggest just going out there and exposing yourself to as much material as possible. Reading light novels or regular books is a great way. 

The more you write the more polished it'll be, and you'll start seeing your ideas and form opinions on them, until you're left with your "style." Getting others to read your work is important too!

Neither of these skins really fit the line. These Gothic Horror skins are more medieval in nature, and those two Vladimir skins are quite far from medieval. Count Vladimir is based on Dracula, who was established in a Victorian era, which is too far in time past the medieval time. Nosferatu was also common in a Victorian setting, though since this skin was actually a Harrowing skin, I would probably expect them to go with a more holiday feel, which again would pull it out of this line.

No, he's right.

Count Vlad isn't inspired by Vlad Tepes, but by the fictional character of Count Dracula, as written by Bram Stoker. And yes, this character was inspired himself by Vlad Tepes, but the story was happening in a different time and mostly in a British context, it was never intended to be a faithful representation of Tepes. The aesthetics associated with Count Dracula in pop culture are definitely Victorian.

To expand on what DeathBurs7 below said, Vlad Tepes was an actual human being, who lived in the mid-1400s. He was a prince of Wallachia, which is now Romania, and launched a very extensive military campaign across Europe and parts of the middle east. He was particularly known for his cruelty and particular fondness for impaling his enemies on spikes as reminders to his other enemies not to cross him. He was very much one of the most iconic warlords that many fictional stories based their warlords off of, and it was Brahm Stoker who borrowed his name when researching for Dracula who inadvertently immortalized him in fiction by linking him to vampirism in his novel. 

That said, Stoker's version of Vlad Tepes is a sophisticate who uses cunning, magic, and trickery to seduce and claim his victims, contrary to the militaristic and tyrannical nature of the real Vlad Tepes. 
The skin, Count Vladimir, is based on Stoker's version of Vlad Tepes - the smooth, sophisticated aristocrat with unearthly beauty, who lived in Victorian times.
The skin, Blood Lord Vladimir, is more based on the actual Vlad Tepes from the medieval era, the imposing warlord who ruled with an iron fist and instilled fear in his enemies and his people with his penchant for blood and murder.
Of these two skins, Blood Lord Vladimir would fit the Gothic Horror theme better than Count Vladimir on the grounds that that skin is based on the tyrant from the medieval era, which appears to be the general era this skin line is pulling inspiration from (based on the face mask Singed wears, which was commonly worn by doctors during this era).
